Q. What is special about PGCE courses at TASC?
A. A small and friendly college, which offers
• Strong pastoral support system through personal tutors who work with trainees throughout the course
• Child- care opportunities on college campus
• Well established partnership systems with schools, which helps trainees as they move through the stages of the course
• Employment rates in all subjects higher than national average
Q. What do I need to get onto the course?
A. Applications are considered on an individual basis. General requirements are
• A degree that has some relevance to the PGCE subject (see subject pages for further details)
• GCSE grade C in Maths and English or equivalent
Q. Does the College require a good honours degree for admission to a PGCE?

A. Normally but there may be exceptions. All candidates need secure subject knowledge, and a depth and breadth of subject knowledge for teaching in secondary schools. The nature of applicants' subject knowledge is explored at interview
Q. Does the College offer Maths and English GCSE equivalent tests?

A. Yes, the College does offer its own internal test for Mathematics but not for English. There are at least three opportunities to take the Maths test between March and the commencement of the course in September. Applicants can take the test as many times as they wish, providing they have a conditional offer of a place on the course. Contact Ann Welborn at 0113 2837268 for further details.
Q. Do I have to attend an interview to get onto the course?
A. Yes, and the interview process is both informative and supportive for starting the course successfully
Q. I have a disability. What help can I get?

A. Our aim is to offer whatever support you need to achieve your potential because at Trinity and All Saints everyone is respected for their individuality and encouraged to make their own contribution to the College community. Please download the appropriate form and email Trish Edwards on t.edwards@leedstrinity.ac.uk
PGCE INTERVIEW DAY REQUIREMENTS
PGCE DYSLEXIA and DISABILITIES SUPPORT ARRANGEMENTS

A. All over the North- East of England, from Darlington to Nottingham and from Hull to Preston as well as in Leeds, Bradford, Wakefield, Dewsbury, Halifax and Huddersfield. It is essential that trainees are placed in schools that have a special partnership with the college to ensure that they receive the support they need.
Q. What are the hours of the average working day on the course?
A. Hours vary according to the stage of the course.

• In College- based training (first twelve weeks) sessions may be time- tabled for 9am until 6pm four days a week. One day per week is reserved for serial visits to the first training school. Many schools start at 8am.
• During school- based training trainees work full- time in schools. The school day is often 8am until 3pm. Meetings may be scheduled after school on some days.
Q. What are my chances of getting a job?
A. The college has a long- standing employment rate of above the national average for its qualified teachers in all subjects.
Q. Can I take the Catholic Teachers Certificate during the PGCE course?

A. If students elect to take the Catholic Education option they will obtain 2 professional modules of the Catholic Certificate in Religious Studies. Other modules can be taken via Open Learning materials available on the website.
Q. Do you offer a PGCE at Postgraduate or Professional level?
A. We offer a PGCE course at both a Professional and a Postgraduate level.

column1: A. Applications must be made through the Graduate Teacher Training Registry ( GTTR ). There is no closing date, but courses can get filled up quickly, so early application is recommended.
